title: Walking Through 1930s Korea with A Day in the Life of Kubo the Novelist

elements.content: I have always preferred novellas and interconnected short stories over lengthy novels. While long novels offer the luxury of prolonged engagement with a story, they often demand an immense memory load—recalling details from volumes past or keeping track of countless characters. For a reader like me, who enjoys letting my thoughts wander while simultaneously visualizing the setting and atmosphere, lengthy novels can be overwhelming. (That said, I do not dislike them; after all, the Harry Potter series remains one of the most enjoyable reads of my life.)

This novel, A Day in the Life of Kubo the Novelist , was therefore an ideal read for me. It offers a well-paced novella-length story with rich background descriptions detailed enough for the reader to feel as though they are walking through the streets of 1930s Gyeongseong (modern-day Seoul) alongside the protagonist. While this novel had a significant impact on Korean literary history, it remains relatively obscure. Since half the joy of writing is self-satisfaction, I decided to discuss it regardless of its niche status.

The novel was written by Park Taewon, who was born in 1909 in Gyeongseong and was active as a writer during the Japanese occupation of Korea. After Korea’s liberation, he moved to North Korea, and his later life remains largely unknown. One of the many pen names he used was “Kubo,” though the character “Kubo” in the novel is written with different Chinese characters. This has led many scholars to view the novel as an autobiographical reflection of the author’s own experiences. Park Taewon was considered highly educated for his time—during an era when even completing high school was seen as a mark of scholarship, he attended Hosei University in Japan before returning to Gyeongseong. His works are known for their meticulous background descriptions, vividly capturing early 20th-century Gyeongseong.

elements.heading: A Personal Reflection on Shorter Fiction

elements.content: The novel follows a single day in the life of a writer in 1930s Gyeongseong. The plot itself is minimal: Kubo leaves his house after listening to yet another lecture from his family about getting a job and getting married. He wanders around the city, meets a friend, and eventually returns home. What makes this novel compelling is not its events but Kubo’s stream-of-consciousness thoughts as he roams the city. As readers, we become immersed in his musings, seamlessly blending into the narrative.

Looking at it another way, turning a simple walk into a novella suggests that the author saw something remarkable or beautiful in the streets of Gyeongseong. Thus, introducing this novel naturally necessitates introducing the city itself. This article follows the novel’s structure, describing the city’s landscape as Kubo experiences it.
Scenery of Jongno Intersection in the 1930s

구보는 갑자기 걸음을 걷기로 한다. 그렇게 우두커니 다리 곁에 가 서 있는 것의 무의미함을 새삼스러이 깨달은 까닭이다. 그는 종로 네거리를 바라보고 걷는다. 구보는 종로 네거리에 아무런 사무도 갖지 않는다. 처음에 그가 아무렇게나 내어놓았던 바른발이 공교롭게도 왼편으로 쏠렸기 때문에 지나지 않는다. 갑자기 한 사람이 나타나 그의 앞을 가로질러 지난다. 구보는 그 사나이와 마주칠 것 같은 착각을 느끼고, 위태롭게 걸음을 멈춘다.

( Kubo suddenly decides to walk, realizing the meaninglessness of standing idly by the bridge. He gazes at Jongno Intersection as he moves forward. Kubo has no particular business at Jongno. His right foot, arbitrarily placed forward, happens to lean left, leading him there. Suddenly, a man crosses his path. Kubo feels the illusion that he will collide with the stranger and precariously halts his steps. )

Kubo’s first stop after leaving home is Jongno Intersection. As the novel suggests, he did not set out with a purpose—his feet simply led him there. Jongno Intersection was one of the busiest areas in Gyeongseong during the Japanese occupation, having been a commercial hub since the Joseon Dynasty. Unlike Honmachi (modern-day Chungmuro), which was home to Japanese settlers, this area remained predominantly Korean, and Park Taewon himself grew up there. It is likely that, for Kubo, Jongno was his familiar neighborhood.
Wandering aimlessly through Jongno, Kubo eventually finds himself in front of a department store.

구보는, 약간 자신이 있는 듯싶은 걸음걸이로 전차 선로를 두 번 횡단하여 화신 상회 앞으로 간다. 그리고 저도 모를 사이에 그의 발은 백화점 안으로 들어서기조차 하였다. 젊은 내외가, 너덧 살 되어 보이는 아이를 데리고 그 곳에가 승강기를 기다리고 있었다. 이제 그들은 식당으로 가서 그들의 오찬을 즐길 것이다. 흘낏 구보를 본 그들 내외의 눈에는 자기네들의 행복을 자랑하고 싶어하는 마음이 엿보였는지도 모른다. 구보는, 그들을 업신여겨 볼까 하다가, 문득 생각을 고쳐, 그들을 축복하여 주려 하였다.

( Kubo, now walking with a bit more confidence, crosses the tram tracks twice and finds himself in front of Hwaseong Department Store. Before he realizes it, he has already stepped inside. A young couple with a child of four or five waits for the elevator. They will soon head to the restaurant to enjoy their lunch. Catching a glimpse of Kubo, the couple’s gaze seems to brim with a desire to display their happiness. Kubo initially considers looking down on them but quickly changes his mind, choosing instead to offer them silent blessings. )

Here, Kubo observes a couple and their child, imagining their plans and happiness. This passage exemplifies the novel’s use of the stream-of-consciousness technique, where Kubo’s thoughts flow naturally without a structured narrative. Many readers might relate to this experience—wandering through familiar streets, letting thoughts drift as they watch passersby.

At the time, the Hwaseong Department Store was one of Gyeongseong’s most prominent landmarks. It was the first modern department store founded by a Korean and remained a major commercial center. Though the store eventually closed, today’s Jongno Tower stands in its place, maintaining the site’s symbolic presence in the city.

The department store featured an expansive shopping space—commonplace for us now but a novel concept at the time. It housed restaurants that served traditional Korean dishes like bibimbap and sinseollo , as well as Western and Japanese cuisine. The family Kubo observes in the novel likely enjoyed one such memorable meal there.

This immersive depiction of Jongno and its surroundings is just the beginning of Kubo’s journey through Gyeongseong. His exploration continues as he navigates the city’s streets, contemplating his place in the world. The following sections will delve deeper into his journey, examining the locations and thoughts that shape A Day in the Life of Kubo the Novelist .
